ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PAYROLL TAX COLLECTIONS
FOR UNEMPLOYMENT
INSURANCE SCHEME


    1. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Finance what is the total amount of payroll tax that has been collected since the tax was introduced up to the latest convenient date; and whether the moneys collected in the form of payroll tax will be used to introduce a social insurance scheme to fulfil the Government's promise to the working people of Singapore.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, actually the Government has never made any promise to introduce a social insurance scheme. What was mentioned was an unemployment insurance scheme which is a small part of social insurance. The

Column: 866

amount of payroll tax since it was introduced was as follows: 

               1965  -  $  7.3 million

               1966  -     9.6 million

               1967  -	  10.0 million

               1968  -	  11.0 million

               1969  -    13.1 million


    The Government has studied the question of unemployment insurance and has sought advice from the International Labour Organisation. The I.L.O. sent an expert, Mr E. D. Tsoucatos, and he was in Singapore from September 1967 to February 1968. Briefly, the findings of this expert are as follows:

    (i) an Unemployment Benefit Scheme alone cannot make any substantial contribution towards the solution of problems created by unemployment in the country. An Unemployment Insurance Scheme in Singapore can

Column: 867

only supplement other measures to reduce unemployment, to provide more employment opportunities and to intensify vocational training;

    (ii) any unemployment insurance scheme should be financed by the contributions both from workers and employers;

    (iii) the scheme should be designed in such a way that it would be self-supporting, covering financial administrative expenses from the workers' and employers' contributions.

    The Government has decided to abandon for the time being the introduction of an unemployment insurance scheme based on payroll tax contributions. There are several reasons for this.

    First, as I said before, the introduction of an unemployment insurance scheme would require contributions not only from the employer, which he is now doing under the payroll tax, but also from the employee. In view of the additional contributions which both employer and employee are making in the enhanced rate to the Central Provident Fund, this is not the right moment to impose further exactions on employees.

    The Government's view is that in the circumstances facing the Republic in the last few years, it would be better to solve problems of unemployment and other social problems related to it through an accelerated programme of economic expansion rather than by arranging transfers of incomes from those who are well off to those who are unfortunate to lose their jobs.

    It is the intention of the Government to use payroll tax contributions to offset additional liabilities which employers incur when they employ discharged national servicemen who are called up for their annual training exercises. This will remove any handicaps which national servicemen may encounter in their efforts to find employment.

TEACHERS
(Particulars of termination of services and resignations)


    2. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education (a) the number of teachers whose services were terminated from 1969 up to the latest convenient date, and on what grounds; (b) the number of teachers who left the service voluntarily, and the reasons for their leaving; (c) how many of the teachers whose services were terminated were (i) trained, and (ii) untrained teachers; and (d) how many of the teachers who left voluntarily were (i) trained, and (ii) untrained teachers.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the period 1st January, 1969, to 17th March, 1970, 39 trained and 46 untrained teachers had their services terminated for unsatisfactory work and conduct, failure to pass probationary or professional examinations, on vacation of office, on medical grounds, or as a result of disciplinary action.

    During the same period, 445 trained and 145 untrained teachers left the service voluntarily to join commercial firms or statutory bodies or for employment in other institutions, such as Nanyang University, Ngee Ann College, or for the purpose of pursuing further studies, or for personal or undisclosed reasons.

MARKET IN JALAN PIPIT
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board what was the cost of building the former market in Jalan Pipit, and why that market was demolished late last year; and what are the reasons for rebuilding another market on the same site, and how much it will cost.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the hawker centre of Jalan Pipit costs $312,000. It is not being

Column: 869

demolished but renovated at a cost of $55,000. This is to provide an increase in the number of stalls from 174 to 220, provide mosaic tiling to the ground floor as the cement floor cannot withstand severe wear and tear, and introduce a closed-drainage system as the present open-drainage system is not very satisfactory.

    The Housing and Development Board is also building another single-storey cooked-food centre adjoining the present two-storey hawker centre at a cost of about $200,000 to provide 40 cooked-food stalls. This is part of the Board's programme to provide sufficient permanent accommodation for hawkers within housing estates.

PAYA LEBAR CONSTITUENCY
(Development proposals)


    4. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether and what development plans the Government has for the Paya Lebar Constituency, especially the area bounded by Airport Road, Kim Chuan Road and the Upper Paya Lebar Road.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no immediate major development proposals in the Paya Lebar Constituency other than proposals for extending and improving Paya Lebar International Airport.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, is it possible for the Minister to give the House more details of the proposals to develop Paya Lebar International Airport?

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are plans for extending the length of the runway. In the long term, there is also a plan to build a second runway parallel to and to the west of the existing runway. This proposal was recommended by the Airport consultants to be constructed by 1982. This is still under examination as there is also a proposal to extend the Airport at Changi.

    The Member for Jurong had the Floor when the House rose on Friday last. He has only one minute left.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I shall make good use of it.

    (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, just before the adjournment last Friday, I was talking about students being too busy to study because they have to take part in extra-curricular activities in order to get more marks. Sir, students almost have to attend a full-day session every day, so much so that when they reach home they are practically exhausted. Consequently, the standard of their lessons in school has dropped.

    Another point I wish to mention is that the grading of marks for participating in extra-curricular activities is rather odd, and gives the impression of being unfair to the students. For instance, in certain extra-curricular activities there is no representative from --

    The Chairman: The time is up. Mr Ong Pang Boon, do you wish to reply?

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, although the Member for Jurong did not have the time to complete what he wanted

Column: 871

to say in respect of extra-curricular activities and the manner in which such activities are graded, I wish to inform him that the problem is in fact, being constantly reviewed. Right now a new scheme is being devised and the Singapore Teachers' Union and the principals are being consulted. Therefore, if the Member has any strong views on the manner in which extra-curricular activities should be graded, I am sure he can put them forward through his own union.

    Last Friday, the Member for Delta mentioned the provision of facilities for the training of kindergarten teachers in Singapore. Kindergartens in Singapore may be broadly divided into two groups - those which are run by the People's Association, a quasi-government body, and the private kindergartens. Teachers in kindergartens run by the People's Association have undergone intensive courses in kindergarten methods. As for the private kindergartens, the position varies from one institution to another. While the registered private kindergartens have a sprinkling of trained teachers, the unregistered private kindergartens, which are in the vast majority, do not have any trained staff.

    In the last eight years, kindergartens have mushroomed all over Singapore. Whether they were motivated politically or for private gain, they reflected a rising standard of living of the people and an awareness of the advantages of a pre-school education in our highly competitive society. Furthermore, for those Asian parents who have not lost their roots in their own society and culture, there is a certain sanctity attached to scholarship. Any form of learning is intrinsically good and is rarely questioned.

    The situation quickly lent itself to exploitation by profiteers and unscrupulous political parties like the Barisan Sosialis. Some of the kindergartens, because of the lack of trained staff, offered children a very poor standard of education and the results were sometimes counter-productive in the manner described by the Member for Delta. On

Column: 872

the other hand, in the kindergartens organised by the Barisan Sosialis, the children were given indoctrination in Communist ideology. While the Government was not in a position to finance universal free kindergarten education, it could improve the situation by organising training facilities for the large number of untrained kindergarten teachers. And when a large pool of trained kindergarten teachers was available, the Government could introduce measures to require all kindergartens to employ only trained teachers. With this in view, in June 1966, my Ministry officials were instructed to explore the feasibility of conducting professional courses for kindergarten teachers. Owing to financial stringency at that time and also because of staffing problems, the proposal did not get started. In 1967, it was decided that the Ministry and the Adult Education Board should jointly organise the training course whereby the Ministry would look after the professional aspects of the course while the Adult Education Board would provide the administrative machinery to run the course. However, for some inexplicable reasons, the course did not get started until May 1969 when the first in-service course in English for 60 teachers in registered kindergartens was started.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1969, the People's Association ran 379 kindergartens for 12,000 children. There were also registered private kindergartens with a total of 175 classes for 5,000 children. The unregistered private kindergartens run by the P.A.P., the Barisan Sosialis, churches and other private individuals probably catered for another 20,000 children. In relation to the need in both the registered and unregistered kindergartens, the training facilities offered at present are grossly inadequate to meet the situation. The Adult Education Board is aware of the situation and I understand that it has decided to introduce a basic kindergarten course in the middle of this year for untrained kindergarten teachers who are not attached to Government, quasi-Government or registered kindergartens.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the question of abolishing post allowances was again raised by the Member for Telok Blangah last Friday. As I pointed out in my reply to the same question in the last Budget debate, my Ministry had made detailed proposals to the Harvey Salaries Commission for the abolition of post allowances and the institution of a unified salary structure which would include promotion scales for the entire education service. However, in its Report, the Salaries Commission recommended the continuance of the existing practice of paying post allowances on promotion but recommended that the Ministry's proposals warranted serious consideration. I understand that the Teachers' Union has since written to the Finance Ministry seeking an interview to thrash out this and other related problems. The Finance Ministry has again referred the matter to my Ministry. It is now left with the Teachers' Union to start the rigmarole once again. My views on this question are quite clear. As the Member for Telok Blangah is aware, in the new promotion posts created in the Technical Education Department, for instance, principals and vice-principals of vocational institutes and industrial training centres, there are no post allowances attached.

    As for the proposal to have an assistant principal in place of a senior assistant in schools, I am afraid no progress has been made. The Member for Telok Blangah, I am sure, is not unaware of the fact that in all salary matters and creation of new posts, more than one Ministry is involved.

    The Member for Telok Blangah complained that primary school teachers have to attend courses in health education and that such courses have been conducted by unqualified teachers. Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been felt for some time that the best way to inculcate sound health habits is to begin with the young children in schools. It is with this in view that a refresher course in health education is being organised for primary school teachers to bring them

Column: 874

up to date in respect of health matters so that they will be in a better position to stimulate greater health consciousness among school children. The lectures are delivered by teachers who have previously attended an intensive course on general and dental health education. However, in view of the large number involved and the shortage of doctors qualified to teach the subject, the Ministry has to make do with such teachers.

    Both the Member for Telok Blangah and the Member for Jurong touched on the duties of Inspectors of Schools. Briefly, it is the duty of inspectors to improve the quality of teaching in all our schools. To achieve this, they visit teachers in schools to offer advice and assistance when necessary. After observing the teachers, they generally hold short discussions with them to stimulate new ideas and approaches to effective teaching, the use of teaching aids, up-to-date information on such matters, methodology and problems arising out of their work. The inspectors are also required to assess the work of teachers who have to satisfy certain service requirements from time to time; for example, crossing efficiency bars or confirmation in the service. However, as the Member for Telok Blangah has pointed out, the Inspectorate staff has not been increased over the years while the student enrolment has gone up. As a result, the inspectors of Schools cannot devote as much time to professional and service matters as they should. This has led to the allegation by the Member for Jurong that the inspectors were feared rather than respected by the teachers. I believe that with the general improvement in the quality of teaching and as our inspectors gain in experience and possibly with some additions to the inspectorate staff, a better relationship between the inspectors and teachers can be achieved.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to congratulate the Ministry of Education on having at last realised the need to abolish post allowances. Sir, they have started off with technical schools. Having

Column: 875

done so, I do not see why promotion posts in other schools still carry post allowances. I realise that this is not just a matter between the Ministry of Education and the Singapore Teachers' Union. I realise that the Treasury is also involved. Sir, you have just heard that the Teachers' Union, after having had a bash at the Ministry of Education, has had a bash at the Treasury. What has the Treasury done? It has referred the matter back to the Ministry of Education. Sir, we cannot just kick the ball about. It is about time that the Ministry of Education and the Treasury decided to rectify this anomaly which the Minister for Education knows has been in existence for the last 20 years. Now the ball is at the foot of the Ministry of Education. And it says that it is waiting for the Teachers' Union to make representations again. Sir, representations have been made over and over again. How much longer are we to wait? The same questions were raised by my colleague, the Member for Punggol, during the debate on the 1967 Estimates. Are we going to wait for next year for the same problem to crop up? Sir, on the question of post allowances and also allowances for senior assistants, I urge the Ministry of Education to pursue actively these matters in the course of this year. And I hope I will not have reason to speak on this again when we meet next year to debate the Estimates.

    The Chairman: Mr N. Govindasamy, I am sure the Minister has taken note of what you have said.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: I hope so, Sir.

    The Chairman: Madam Chan, are you withdrawing your amendment?

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Sir, before I withdraw my amendment, I wish to say a few words. The Minister for Education has said that, in view of the present financial position, it is not possible to conduct training courses for kindergarten

Column: 876

teachers at present. Sir, with the help of the Teachers' Training College and the Technical Education Department, perhaps some training courses can be arranged for kindergarten teachers. As we all know that children are the future pillars of our society, they should be well educated while they are young. For instance, if we plant a tree and we do not give it enough nourishment or fertiliser, it will not live up to expectations. In the end, whatever effort and energy we spend on cultivating it will be lost. Therefore, if we want to have good fruits, we must have good trees. It is necessary to provide the trees with enough fertiliser during the early stages. If the Government thinks that there is not enough money to conduct training courses for kindergarten teachers, then perhaps it can take other alternative measures. For instance, kindergarten teachers can pay for the training which is organised for them.

    The Chairman: I am sure the Minister would love to answer Madam Chan's questions!

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, my criticism was that the course for the training of kindergarten teachers had not started earlier and expanded to the scale that I would like to see it expanded. In fact, I shall be pursuing quite energetically this question of training kindergarten teachers in the next few months.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0701 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead l005*.

    (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Mr Teong Eng Siong, Mr Ang Nam Piau, Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon, Mr J. F. Conceicao and Mr P. Selvadurai)

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the last ten years there has been tremendous progress in the development of education in the Republic, and many kinds

Column: 877

of reform have been carried out. However, the same cannot be said about educational research. There is a distinct lack of advance in this field. This aspect has been neglected. Is it right that we should neglect it? I think we should give more thought to it.

    In January 1968, there was a seminar on education which was attended by teachers from all schools. There was a suggestion to set up an educational research centre. This was accepted at the preliminary meeting of the seminar, and was subsequently submitted to the Ministry for consideration. However, no one is in a position to know what is the outcome of this suggestion.

    Following this, there was a suggestion in this House in May 1968 that every encouragement should be given to set up an educational research centre. The reason why I am touching on this point is that I feel that research in education plays a very important role in the development of our national education. Let us take a look at our educational development. We have carried out many educational reforms. Many of them are novel in nature, but this does not mean that all of them are good. I had occasion to read an article on educational research. Sir, permit me to quote one or two sentences from this particular article. This article says that we have a fine set of educational theory, but we lack systematic and scientific research in education. Advancement in education must be matched by advancement in educational research.

    The Chairman: Which publication are you referring to, Mr Tay?

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): I am referring to an article in a booklet published by the T.T.C.

    The Chairman: Is this booklet with you? Do you have the particulars of the book; for example, the year of publication and the volume number, so that the Minister can refer to it later

Column: 878



    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): At present I do not have this publication with me, but if the Minister requires it, I will give it to him later on.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the two sentences that I quoted just now were in regard to the importance of research in education. My main point is to emphasise that research in education should also be carried out.

    Let us look at the educational reforms which have been carried out. For example, the system of integrated schools, the teaching of Civics and History in Chinese in English Schools, and the teaching of Mathematics and Science in English in Chinese schools. All these are important educational reforms. They not only reflect our educational policy, but they are also part of our national policy. They go to prove that our educational objectives are ideal, but they do not prove that we have rational and scientific research in education.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to make certain criticisms of the policy of teaching Mathematics and Science through the use of English in Chinese schools. What is the objective of this reform? When defining the objective of bilingualism some two years ago, the Minister for Education stated that we have been trying to carry out the teaching of Mathematics and Science in English in non-English schools, and the result of this experiment has been very encouraging. This is but a start towards the objectives that we have for our educational reforms. Our belief is that, apart from teaching the second language as a subject, and using it as a medium of instruction to teach other subjects, it will help in better progress in mastering the language. No doubt, the Research and Statistics Unit in the Ministry of Education has conducted a survey into the teaching of Mathematics and Science in Government Chinese Primary schools in Primary one and two classes. As the Minister has said, the result of this experiment has been very encouraging. However, the report of this survey has now been shelved and kept as a highly

Column: 879

confidential document. Ordinary people are not in a position to know what its contents are.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I may be ignorant of matters pertaining to education, but why is it that such a survey, which has a grave bearing on our educational reform, should select only certain Government schools for this experiment? I ask the Minister these questions. How many Government schools were selected for such a survey, and what was the number of Primary one and two pupils involved in it? Were the conclusions of this survey applied to all Chinese Primary schools? Furthermore, the statement is made that in addition to teaching the second language as a second language, if it is also used as a medium of instruction to teach other subjects, it will result in better progress in mastering the language. This means that if we use the second language to teach other subjects, it will help our pupils to acquire knowledge of the second language in a shorter time. This is only a hypothetical assumption. There is no evidence to show that this is the result of the experiment. In my view, the printed language is only a tool, and the ability to use any language is the ability to manipulate a skill. Let us call it a "printed language". On the other hand, from the point of view of teaching Mathematics, mathematical symbols are also a kind of tool. Let us call it "mathematical language". The question is this: is it true that the teaching of Mathematics in a certain language will result in a better mastery of that language? I think this question merits our detailed study. The teaching of Mathematics and Science through the use of English in Chinese schools is already an accomplished fact. I have no intention to reopen here the debate on the merits and demerits of this policy, but certain questions arise. We have carried out many educational reforms, and we must be courageous enough to admit that not all of them have been successful. Our vocational schools are examples of the failure of one of our reforms. We should not embark upon a reform in haste without

Column: 880

taking into consideration all the relevant factors. More important, it is not enough just to have an educational ideology. It must be complemented and supported by scientific, rational and systematic research into education, otherwise the time and money spent will be wasted. It will be not a boon but a bane to our educational system. To embark upon reforms in education is, I feel, a question of principle, but how these reforms are to be carried out and what results they will bring is a question of detail. I believe there are people who share my sentiments that educational reforms must be matched and supported by educational research.

    Lastly, may I be allowed to pose three questions? Firstly, since the Government has carried out a survey into the teaching of Mathematics and Science in English in Government Chinese Primary schools, are the conclusions of this experiment valid for all Chinese Primary schools?

3.15 p.m.

    Secondly, is there a need to reassess the policy of teaching Mathematics and Science in the English language in Chinese schools? Thirdly, what are the prospects of setting up a National Education Research Centre?

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, everyone knows that we practise equality in all the four streams of education. In the last few years, we have placed emphasis on technical education so that more technical personnel can be trained to meet the requirements of our industrialisation programme.

    I would now like to talk on vocational and technical education. There are limited places in the institutes for technical education. According to statistics, the enrolment this year is about 8,000 students. However, the institutes are only able to absorb about 1,000 students, and about 7,000 students are unable to get places in these institutes. Can the Minister inform me how many places are available in the technical institutes?

Column: 881



    Sir, as we require a great number of technical personnel at this time, we must set up more technical schools so that we will be able to produce in the shortest possible time the necessary technical personnel that we need. I remember the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education saying that about 35,000 technical personnel will be trained in two or three years. But if we can only enrol about 1,000 students at present, the training of 35,000 technical personnel will take about 30 years. By that time, our factories will have closed down, or we will have to recruit more and more technicians from abroad. This is a matter of crucial importance, and I do not know if the Minister has any new plans on the training of technical personnel.

    Another problem is the special classes conducted by the Adult Education Board. These special classes, of course, are commendable because they are able to cater for the thousands of students who are not able to go to secondary schools. Their ages range from 14 to 15, and the Government has set up these classes so as to give them certain technical training to enable them to acquire certain skills which will be useful to them when they go on to the labour market. However, what is regrettable is that these classes are mostly concentrated in urban schools. In many schools in the rural areas, for example, in Sembawang and Nee Soon, such classes have not been set up. It is, therefore, very inconvenient for those who live in the rural areas to attend these classes in the city, and the expenses incurred on transport will be an extra burden on their parents. I would like to plead for those students who live in the rural areas, and urge the Ministry of Education to consider setting up such special classes in the rural areas in order to cope with the demand.

    The other question is about food stalls in school tuckshops. I have received many complaints from stallholders who are licensed to sell food and drinks to school children. One complaint is that the rental is too high. For

Column: 882

example, a stall selling sweets at 5 cents or 10 cents has to pay a monthly rent of $20 to $30. Their profit is very small, and with such high rentals, it is impossible for them to earn a livelihood. I hope the Minister will consider reducing the rentals for such stalls. We know that most of these stallholders are former recipients of public assistance from the Social Welfare Department. The rule is that if they are given a stall licence, they will not receive any public assistance.
